Bug.Summery: AbstractEditPartViewer.setRootEditPart() does not deactivate the old edit part
Bug.WithStack: setRootEditPart(RootEditPart) in AbstractEditPartViewer should first deactivate the old root edit part, and then set its viewer to null. Fixed. It now checks to see if there was an old root, and if it was active, it deactivates it, and then sets its viewer to null.
Bug.WithOutStack: setRootEditPart(RootEditPart) in AbstractEditPartViewer should first deactivate the old root edit part, and then set its viewer to null. Fixed. It now checks to see if there was an old root, and if it was active, it deactivates it, and then sets its viewer to null.

Bug.Summery: Review InternalPlatform.handleException
Bug.WithStack: This method catches and discards Throwable. It needs to be cleaned up. I have moved ISafeRunnable.handleException outside the try/catch because it caused rethrown cancelations to be lost. See bug 45139 for details. I restored the original code (before Equinox merge) and simplified the logging section to use the runtime plug-in id.
Bug.WithOutStack: This method catches and discards Throwable. It needs to be cleaned up. I have moved ISafeRunnable.handleException outside the try/catch because it caused rethrown cancelations to be lost. See bug 45139 for details. I restored the original code (before Equinox merge) and simplified the logging section to use the runtime plug-in id.

Bug.Summery: Search Dialog box does not remember last selected search tab
Bug.WithStack:
This is more of an annoyance than anything, but it would be really nice if the Search Dialog box would restore the last selected tab between search attempts.
A typical use case for me would be searching for something and have that search come up empty a number of times before I finally submit a search finds what I'm looking for. If I'm doing a Java search, I have to select the Java search tab every single time because the default behavior always actives the File search tab. You get the idea. Not exactly the same bug, but the resolution is that same. Please reopen if you don't agree.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 33710 ***

Bug.Summery: Expose dialogs for creating classpath entries
Bug.WithStack:
This is a request to provide non-internal access to the dialogs used to create classpath entries within the JDT UI. These would be simple dialogs or perhaps even just helper methods (e.g. IClasspathEntry[] showExternalJARDialog(Shell shell)) that could be used to present the user with the same dialogs and return a classpath entry. Specifically, the dialogs that appear by clicking on the following buttons on the Java Build Path properties, Libraries tab: Add JARs... Add External JARs... Add Variable.. Add Library... Add Class Folder...
Exposing these dialogs would allow downstream JDT users to create and edit classpath entries outside of the regular JDT dialogs. For instance, providing a UI to set a server's classpath in an editor.
Currently, this is done by duplicating the dialogs. Maintenance of duplicate dialogs is an issue, as well as a usability problem since the dialogs are inevitably different. Martin, can you comment on the impact of making such dialogs API. makes sense to add API here Tim, where do you want to use the dialogs ? New class 'BuildPathDialogAccess' is now offering access to dialogs to select an configure class path entries and properties Closing.

This is a request to provide non-internal access to the dialogs used to create classpath entries within the JDT UI. These would be simple dialogs or perhaps even just helper methods (e.g. IClasspathEntry[] showExternalJARDialog(Shell shell)) that could be used to present the user with the same dialogs and return a classpath entry. Specifically, the dialogs that appear by clicking on the following buttons on the Java Build Path properties, Libraries tab: Add JARs... Add External JARs... Add Variable.. Add Library... Add Class Folder...
Exposing these dialogs would allow downstream JDT users to create and edit classpath entries outside of the regular JDT dialogs. For instance, providing a UI to set a server's classpath in an editor.

Martin, can you comment on the impact of making such dialogs API. makes sense to add API here Tim, where do you want to use the dialogs ? New class 'BuildPathDialogAccess' is now offering access to dialogs to select an configure class path entries and properties Closing.

Bug.Summery: META-INF "package" should not be provided
Bug.WithStack:
i20031202
In the plugin converter, when generating the Provided-Package entry, we add all directories in the plug-in classpath that contain any files.
Should we include the META-INF directory in that list (as we do now)? I don't see any value in doing that, and it is an extra entry that is not likely to be used at all (at least not across bundles). I agree. I put in because I've seen some weird case in wsad, but I think we should get rid of it until we understand better what was the real use case. Code fix is in. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
i20031202
In the plugin converter, when generating the Provided-Package entry, we add all directories in the plug-in classpath that contain any files.
Should we include the META-INF directory in that list (as we do now)? I don't see any value in doing that, and it is an extra entry that is not likely to be used at all (at least not across bundles). I agree. I put in because I've seen some weird case in wsad, but I think we should get rid of it until we understand better what was the real use case. Code fix is in. Closing.

Bug.Summery: Command.isEnabled() always replies "false"
Bug.WithStack:
At least, this was the case a week ago when I last checked. As originally designed, command should only reply that it is not enabled if its handler isn't enabled. And, there should be a strong correlation between enabled command and enabled menu items. As it is right now, all commands are always disabled.
I'm raising this as a bug to help us track this, and because John Arthorne (Bug 48083) has noticed the consequences of this problem.
I think this is a "major" part of the command functionality. :P ICommand no longer has isEnabled(), but the equivalent command.getAttributeValue("enabled") should work fine now.
Bug.WithOutStack:
At least, this was the case a week ago when I last checked. As originally designed, command should only reply that it is not enabled if its handler isn't enabled. And, there should be a strong correlation between enabled command and enabled menu items. As it is right now, all commands are always disabled.
I'm raising this as a bug to help us track this, and because John Arthorne (Bug 48083) has noticed the consequences of this problem.
I think this is a "major" part of the command functionality. :P ICommand no longer has isEnabled(), but the equivalent command.getAttributeValue("enabled") should work fine now.

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] Provide availableInDialog property on key bindings
Bug.WithStack:
Provide a read-only property -- availableInDialog -- on key bindings. This property should be available to developers, but not visible to the user. It indicates when a key binding is appropriate for use in the dialog.
(this enhancement is just so i don't forget) This is part of my work for M8. I've committed changes allowing this property to be changed on the keys preference page, and to be read in from XML. I still need to update the schema and doc -- advertising its existence. I also need to provide the appropriate hooks for the key binding service to use this information. This service is provided, though the key binding resolution (including pieces of the command manager) are still broken. i wish i had of got to you a day earlier. i'm not sure what this change is (i'm not sure why one would have key bindings work on dialogs - its really the handler one cares about), but my big changes last night made it (almost) possible to have key bindings in dialogs. basically by tonight HandlerSubmission will be able to discriminate by dialog/main workbench window/or both for purposes of solving handlers for particular command ids.
it will require almost no code changes. perhaps we can talk about this tomorrow morning?
i disagree with this bug, and its fix. i think the fix should be reversed and the bug resolved as invalid. I agree with Chris' proposed alternative, and Chris has rolled back these changes. Closing as INVALID. We approached this problem from another angle.

(this enhancement is just so i don't forget) This is part of my work for M8. I've committed changes allowing this property to be changed on the keys preference page, and to be read in from XML. i disagree with this bug, and its fix. i think the fix should be reversed and the bug resolved as invalid. I agree with Chris' proposed alternative, and Chris has rolled back these changes. Closing as INVALID. We approached this problem from another angle.

Bug.Summery: When using the UI multiplier, the zoom levels should be scaled accordingly
Bug.WithStack: getZoomAsText() returns zoom * multiplier. However, getZoomLevelsAsText() return the original zoom values, and hence, some of them are not valid. Fixed. getZoomLevelsAsText now applies the multiplier to all possible zoom levels. Forgot to mark this as fixed earlier.
Bug.WithOutStack: getZoomAsText() returns zoom * multiplier. However, getZoomLevelsAsText() return the original zoom values, and hence, some of them are not valid. Fixed. getZoomLevelsAsText now applies the multiplier to all possible zoom levels. Forgot to mark this as fixed earlier.

Bug.Summery: Collaboration Webmatrix-like feature

Lines.Line: - bug tracking integration
- chat
- mail client for forums
- web browser
- documentation plugings?
That is fine, but the Team component or Eclipse SDK, is the platform. We hope
that others (e.g. hint that you can help) will provide these tools. If there is
something in the platform that makes it impossible to build these tools, then
please open a bug report for the specific cases.

Bug.WithStack:
Hello, I would propose a feature we can find into WebMatrix and also into VisualStudio.Net; it is a collaborative feature : we can then access directly through an eclipse view in a perspective to the miscellaneous Eclipse forums, documentations, bug parade, plugins available, ... I really think that kind of feature is important for Eclipse by accelarating the information exchange between users, developpers... regards Xavier Basically you want Team to provide: - bug tracking integration - chat - mail client for forums - web browser - documentation plugings? That is fine, but the Team component or Eclipse SDK, is the platform. We hope that others (e.g. hint that you can help) will provide these tools. If there is something in the platform that makes it impossible to build these tools, then please open a bug report for the specific cases.
Or if you really think that Team should provide specific features, open enhancement requests for each one. Re-Hello, You know, my proposal is simply the proposal of an eclipse user from the beginning (2 years), who daily use Eclipse ;-) I'm also a user of Visual Studio (and web matrix), and even if I like at most Eclipse, I also know what I like in VisualStudio ;-) And I only tell you that for instance the Community view in web matrix is very useful, and it could be very easily plugged into Eclipse as a view... The content of this view (see WebMatrix) is simply a list of the following features : *ASP.NET Online -> Eclipse.net online **web matrix online -> eclipse platform online **web site -> eclipse.net *ASP.NET ressources -> Eclipse ressources **ASP.NET books -> Eclipse books and articles **ASP.NET web hosting -> Community projects for instance *Web Matrix forum **general discussion **bug report -> could open the bug report in a browser not obligatory in eclipse!!! *ASP.NET forums ** misc... forums (announcements, getting started, SWT, GEF, ...) *ASP.NET newsgroup ** misc... eclipse.org.ui, eclipse.org.team, ...
We could also add another category for the plugins developped by users...
As you see, it is not a big issue... It is just providing a standardize view common for all the users, an entry point... I don't say that everything must be inside Eclipse (eg an internal web browser, an internal bug tracking system, ...), just a means to open the existing features offered onto the web site...obviously, it can be extended in the future... regards Xavier This bug has not been touched for 2 years. Closing as WONTFIX. Please reopen if you feel this is still an important issue.

Bug.Summery: [GlobalActions] "Forward" & "Back" global actions dont seem to be global

Lines.Line: - in the Package Explorer, select a project, package or folder
- Navigate > Go Into
- Navigate > Go To > Back
- Navigate > Go To > Forward
- Navigate > Go To > Up

Bug.WithStack:
I tried registering my own actions against the Forward and Back global actions, and my action doesnt seem to be invoked.
here is the code snippet:
// register with global action service. IActionBars actionBars = introArea.getActionBars(); actionBars.setGlobalActionHandler(ActionFactory.FORWARD.getId(),forwardAction); actionBars.setGlobalActionHandler(ActionFactory.BACK.getId(),backAction);
am I missing something? The above code does not enable any of the Forward or Back action in the Eclipse Navigate menu. If I use PREVIOUS and NEXT all words well.
thanks Mazen Faraj nick, can you comment on this? Perhaps these methods haven't been implemented yet. It's unclear that IIntroSite should extend IWorkbenchSite since it doesn't really belong to a page or a window. I'd keep them separate for now, add what you need to IIntroSite, then look at refactoring it under one of the existing site interfaces later.
Huh? Nick, did you mean that as a comment for Bug 49117? And if so, did you mean to assign this bug to me? This seems to be related to bug 49117 since Mazen's code above is talking to the intro area. I was guessing that setGlobalActionHandler on the IIntroArea's IIActionBars is not implemented, and that you were the one implementing this.
I assumed by intro area he meant the hacked-up version they were using internally. NONE of the new IIntro stuff should work at the moment, only the interfaces have been checked in. If PREVIOUS and NEXT are working for him he must be using existing API. Apologies for the confusion! :) Yes, Kim is right.. I opned this defect a while back when I was playing around with a hacked IIntroArea implemented as a view. I got the actionBars throught the Eclipse view and I tried registering these two global actions but the code didnt work. The defect is still valid, confusing but valid.
and yes, the above code with PREVIOUS and NEXT actions works. Is the intro area implemented as a view in the hacked up version? If so, do the FORWARD and BACK actions get retargeted properly if registered in the view itself? Note that the view must be the active part.
Nick, yes, the IIntroArea was hacked up as a view in this defect. But lets get the IIntro stuff out of the picture. I have a view that has the above code snippet. I can override the NEXT and PREVIOUS actions from the Navigate menu, but I cant do that for the FORWARD and BACK actions. Am I missing something? Arent these actions global?
Yes, these are both retargetable and they both work for regular views. Try the following: - in the Package Explorer, select a project, package or folder - Navigate > Go Into - Navigate > Go To > Back - Navigate > Go To > Forward - Navigate > Go To > Up
Note that these actions are different from the editor history navigation actions in the main toolbar, which are not retargetable. The arrows in the Package Explorer's local toolbar -do- correspond to FORWARD and BACKWARD though.
Nick, I guess that was my source of confusion. I was referring to what you call "editor history navigation actions in the main toolbar". ie: from main menu go to Navigate -> Back / Forward.
You say that they are not retargetable, which is fine. I guess these are dedicated for editor hitory navigation, and you dont want to confuse that. ok. But then isnt it a bit confusing to make the Next and Previous (in the same drop down menu) retargettable? while the Back and Forward are not? Not only that, the Next and Previous are context sensistive, while the Back and Forward are not. Its just a bit confusing to absorb. Please correct me if Im wrong. Also, maybe I havent searched enough, but I could have sworn that I read in the javadoc somewhere taht the Forward and Back are part of the actions that can be retargetted.
Mazen.

Bug.Summery: Select an element in the AntView after single deletion
Bug.WithStack:
Since we do not allow multi-select in the ant view it is rather painful to quickly several buildfiles (but not all).
After deleting a buildfile, we should set the selection to a remaining buildfile. Fixed in AntView. Please verify Luc. Verified. Please update the build notes, Darin S.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Since we do not allow multi-select in the ant view it is rather painful to quickly several buildfiles (but not all).
After deleting a buildfile, we should set the selection to a remaining buildfile. Fixed in AntView. Please verify Luc. Verified. Please update the build notes, Darin S.

Bug.Summery: getDataFile on the eclipse classloader should return the .metadata location
Bug.WithStack:
Bundle.getDataFile() should be mapped to the .metadata location of the underlying plugin. However we need to be careful to the version number of the plugin. Why is the version number an issue?
Because we may have several plugins with the same id resolved at the same time, and that may not necessarily want to share the data. This is for example already a pb with xerces for example.
However one conter argument to putting the number is that when I move from one version to higher version I loose the metadata...
Right. Just as note, the case you mention has always been true (I am not saying it should not be improved). It seems that we kind assumed that "real" plug-ins (the ones that used the Eclipse API) would always have extensions or extension points, so (since this forced them to be singletons) that was not a problem.
A question: what would the location be for a bundle that does not have a global name?
I would say it is in the same place than the eclipse metadata but instead we would use the long id? in the first comment I think you were talking of the generation number? or did you realy mean version number?
I think we should just do whatever Eclipse does today. There are clearly problems when you have multiple versions of the same plugin We can improve upon that in the future. Is this still an issue? Jeff you have mentioned an API that allows a plugin get access to a persistent storage area. What is this API and what does eclipse currently map that directory too?
Right now the eclipse adaptor will map a File object returned by BundleContext.getDataFile() to the directory .metadata\bundles\<bundle id>\data\ of the workspace.
Where <bundle id> is the long bundle id, not the global bundle name. This data area stays the same acrossed bundle updates so if you update a bundle the data area is not removed and is reused by the newly updated bundle. Is this what you are looking for? I think the eclipse api should map to the same directory. Does this cause migration issues? Should we really map the bundle's data area to the location used by the eclipse API? Plugin.getStateLocation() is basically the same as BundleContext.getDataFile ("/").
Unfortunately as you point out we now have two places, the Eclipse and OSGi places. Just like the URL stuff, the Eclipse implementation is a bit bogus because like much of Eclipse, I don't tihnk it handles multiple versions that well. However the OSGi mechanism is brittle with respect to plugin install order. For example, it is extremely common for people to keep the same workspace (and thus metadata/bundle state area) but run different Eclipse biulds, or confgiruations on it. I suspect (though it should be verified) that losing this would be annoying.
For example, I think the UI keeps the workbench layout etc in there somewhere. Losing all your windows when you change builds would be less than optimal. Not sure what to do We have decided to make the Bundle data location to be located under the configuration location. This defect suggests it should be under the .metadata which is the under the instance location. This will not be fixed.

Bug.Summery: TVT: unexternalized string "Another session is already running..."

Lines.Line: 1- install the English product
2- unzip the NL fragment on top
3- launch eclipse in the French locale
4- while eclipse is running, launch eclipse again
=>get error message described in the description above in English. The string
needs to be externalized for translation.
This message is produced by the eclipse executable.
We don't have an externalization story for messages here.

Bug.WithStack:
Driver: eclipse2.1.1 (window version) NL fragment: eclipse2.1.1-sdk-win-LanguagePackFeature
Description: Unexternalized string "Another session is already running in the associated workspace. If this is not the case, please delete this ".lock" file in the workspace ".medatdata" directory and try starting the platform again.
Step to recreated: 1- install the English product 2- unzip the NL fragment on top 3- launch eclipse in the French locale 4- while eclipse is running, launch eclipse again =>get error message described in the description above in English. Bug.Summery: [Preferences] File associations preferences are not exported

Lines.Line: 1. modify the file associations (I add 'Ant Editor' to *.xml)
2. export the preferences
3. launch eclipse on a new workspace
4. import the preferences
The file associations preference page contains the default values
Another one to look at....
This bug also happens on Windows XP. I am currently investigating.

Bug.WithStack:
I20031203
1. modify the file associations (I add 'Ant Editor' to *.xml) 2. export the preferences 3. launch eclipse on a new workspace 4. import the preferences The file associations preference page contains the default values Another one to look at.... This bug also happens on Windows XP. I am currently investigating.
I am using: Eclipse Platform Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200404290010 After tracing the code, here are my observations:
The problem is that the editorRegisry was only being updated on start up, which means that the file associations are loaded from the registry on start up only. As a consequence, importing preferences that contain file associations had no effect until you restarted the workbench (you should see all the imported setting if you just restart the workbench).
I am adding code to PlatformUIPreferenceListener to update the registry when a preference has changed (thanks to Tod's help :) ).
A patch will follow shortly.
Created attachment 10189 File associations preferences patch
Added an "initializeFromStorage()" call to PlatformUIPreferenceListener class when file associations preferences have changed. Re-assigning to Doug so you can use the patch if he decides to. oops. If he decides to use it... :) I undid some of the formatting changes in the listener -- just so that the diff is a bit clearer. Tested the code, and it seems to work for the test case given.
Thanks for your help.... The fixes cause a regression in behaviour. Importing a preference file displays a dialog complaining the editor associations could not be imported. Tracing through the code, it is caused by
java.io.FileNotFoundException: /home/dpollock/Source/Eclipse/Workspaces/SelfHosted/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.ui.workbench/resourcetypes.xml (No such file or directory)
On line 643 of EditorRegistry. Ines: could you look at this please? Created attachment 10405 Preference File to Import Yes, I was able to reproduce the problem just now. The patch has also introduced another regression (duplicating the Editor Selection list). I have found the problem and I am currently investigating a solution. I am looking for a method that updates the "EditorRegistry". The "getEditorRegistry().initializeFromStorage()" serves a different purpose and introduces other complications. I logged another bug report (Bug 61449) to obtain more information about which method should be used in this case. Reverted the fix. Created attachment 10649 Revised patch to "org.eclipse.ui.workbench"
Ines: can you clean this up. Created attachment 10659 Patch for the file association issues
Here is a cleaner version of the latest patch. I also added code to handle external editor associations. It seems to work. The only caveat is that the preference file Doug attached contains random characters at the end that were causing some problems. Re-assigning to Doug so he can use the patch then close this bug. The patch has been applied in CVS. Verified on Build id: 200405181200 using Mac OS X. Verified with Build id: 200405190010 on Mac OS X and Windows XP. Verified by Ines.

Bug.Summery: Source code not always found in debugger
Bug.WithStack:
This report includes a description of my setup, a description of the problem, a description of the source of the problem, and a description of two possible solutions.
SETUP: My setup is a little complex. I think that most of this is irrelevent, but I'm including it all just in case.
I'm running Eclipse 2.1.2 with CDT 1.2 on Windows XP. I have a current cygwin installation (as of 2003-12-4) and prc-tools 2.3 installed (<http://prc- tools.sf.net>). I'm running from a drive (K:) that's mapped to my Documents directory (C:\Documents and Settings\Keith Rollin.PALMSOURCE\My Documents). My workspace (K:\Projects\Eclipse\plugins) is outside of my Eclipse directory (K:\Downloads\eclipse\2.1.2\eclipse). I launch Eclipse with a shortcut that specifies the following command line: K:\Downloads\eclipse\2.1.2 \eclipse\eclipse.exe -data k:\Projects\Eclipse\plugins. My runtime workspace is in the normal location relative to the main workspace (K:\Projects\Eclipse\runtime-workspace). I am using the Eclipse for Palm OS plugin (<http://www.redfelineninja.dsl.pipex.com/software.html>) to debug Palm applications. Because I'm developing extensions, most of my debugging is in a runtime IDE. The problem I describe occurs both in the runtime IDE as well as the host IDE.
PROBLEM: The problem is that source files are not always found in the debugger. Assume that I've developed a Palm application, have launched under the control of the Palm OS Emulator and the m68k-palmos-gdb debugger that comes with prc-tools, and that my Palm application has crashed and that I'm looking at a stack crawl in the debugger. Clicking on a stack frame that corresponds to a function in my application results in a page saying that the source file cannot be found.
SOURCE: I think I've traced the problem to a couple of methods in CSourceLocator. findFileByAbsolutePath() is given the path of a file to look for. As part of its operation, it creates a File on that path, calls File.getCanonicalPath, and then passes the result to CSourceLocator.findFile (). findFile iterates over all project members, looking for an IFile that has the same path.
The problem is that findFileByAbsolutePath is given a path where the drive letter is lower-case. findFile also generates project item paths where the drive letter is lower-case. However, the call to getCanonicalPath converts the lower-case drive letter to an upper-case drive letter, cause the strict string match between the target path and the project item paths to fail.
Eventually, it occurred to me that the paths being generated had a lower-case drive letter because I'd specified a lower-case drive letter in the command line in the shortcut I use to launch Eclipse. Changing that, and changing the path to the runtime-workspace in my launch configuration (which appears to have been generated from the path I'd specified in the shortcut) fixed the problem.
As an interesting workaround, I also noticed that the source files could be found if my project was not in the workspace directory (that is, when I'd imported an existing project into my workspace from another location on my hard drive without actually copying the files into my workspace). I never bothered to track down why this was so.
SOLUTION: One obvious fix to this problem would be to make more use of getCanonicalPath, thus generating consistant paths that could be compared against each other. However, I have another suggestion. While tracking down this bug, I noticed that the source-locator routines were given a simple file name (no path information), and were asked to find a file with that name in the project. The algorithm used to perform this search involved iterating over the project, prefixing the file name with every possible path in the project, and then iterating over the project again looking for a file with that full path. It seems to me that a much simpler approach would be to iterate over the project, and for each IFile, to see if the file name (without the path) matched the simple file name that was passed to the source locator. PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 Moving the target milestone to 3.0.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 48118 ***

Bug.Summery: Source code not always found in debugger
Bug.WithStack:
This report includes a description of my setup, a description of the problem, a description of the source of the problem, and a description of two possible solutions.
SETUP: My setup is a little complex. I think that most of this is irrelevent, but I'm including it all just in case.
I'm running Eclipse 2.1.2 with CDT 1.2 on Windows XP. I have a current cygwin installation (as of 2003-12-4) and prc-tools 2.3 installed (<http://prc- tools.sf.net>). I'm running from a drive (K:) that's mapped to my Documents directory (C:\Documents and Settings\Keith Rollin.PALMSOURCE\My Documents). My workspace (K:\Projects\Eclipse\plugins) is outside of my Eclipse directory (K:\Downloads\eclipse\2.1.2\eclipse). I launch Eclipse with a shortcut that specifies the following command line: K:\Downloads\eclipse\2.1.2 \eclipse\eclipse.exe -data k:\Projects\Eclipse\plugins. My runtime workspace is in the normal location relative to the main workspace (K:\Projects\Eclipse\runtime-workspace). I am using the Eclipse for Palm OS plugin (<http://www.redfelineninja.dsl.pipex.com/software.html>) to debug Palm applications. Because I'm developing extensions, most of my debugging is in a runtime IDE. The problem I describe occurs both in the runtime IDE as well as the host IDE.
PROBLEM: The problem is that source files are not always found in the debugger. Assume that I've developed a Palm application, have launched under the control of the Palm OS Emulator and the m68k-palmos-gdb debugger that comes with prc-tools, and that my Palm application has crashed and that I'm looking at a stack crawl in the debugger. Clicking on a stack frame that corresponds to a function in my application results in a page saying that the source file cannot be found.
SOURCE: I think I've traced the problem to a couple of methods in CSourceLocator. findFileByAbsolutePath() is given the path of a file to look for. As part of its operation, it creates a File on that path, calls File.getCanonicalPath, and then passes the result to CSourceLocator.findFile (). findFile iterates over all project members, looking for an IFile that has the same path.
The problem is that findFileByAbsolutePath is given a path where the drive letter is lower-case. findFile also generates project item paths where the drive letter is lower-case. However, the call to getCanonicalPath converts the lower-case drive letter to an upper-case drive letter, cause the strict string match between the target path and the project item paths to fail.
Eventually, it occurred to me that the paths being generated had a lower-case drive letter because I'd specified a lower-case drive letter in the command line in the shortcut I use to launch Eclipse. Changing that, and changing the path to the runtime-workspace in my launch configuration (which appears to have been generated from the path I'd specified in the shortcut) fixed the problem.
As an interesting workaround, I also noticed that the source files could be found if my project was not in the workspace directory (that is, when I'd imported an existing project into my workspace from another location on my hard drive without actually copying the files into my workspace). I never bothered to track down why this was so.
SOLUTION: One obvious fix to this problem would be to make more use of getCanonicalPath, thus generating consistant paths that could be compared against each other. However, I have another suggestion. While tracking down this bug, I noticed that the source-locator routines were given a simple file name (no path information), and were asked to find a file with that name in the project. The algorithm used to perform this search involved iterating over the project, prefixing the file name with every possible path in the project, and then iterating over the project again looking for a file with that full path. It seems to me that a much simpler approach would be to iterate over the project, and for each IFile, to see if the file name (without the path) matched the simple file name that was passed to the source locator. This code including the search algorithm has been changed since 1.2 and will be released in 1.2.1. Unfortunately, 'getCanonicalPath' doesn't work if the workspace is a symbolic link (bug 43372) and we decided not to use it. I'll try your examples with the new version.
PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 *** Bug 48117 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fixed.

Bug.Summery: [Navigator] file icons are not updated when file associations are modified.

Lines.Line: 1. launch Eclipse on a new workspace
2. create a project
3. create a file named 'test1.xml'
The new file is displayed with the default (text) file icon.
4. associate '*.xml' files to the ant editor in
window>preferences>workbench>file associations
5. create a file named 'test2.xml'
The new file is displayed with the ant file icon, test1.xml is still displayed
with the default file icon.

Bug.WithStack:
I20031203
1. launch Eclipse on a new workspace 2. create a project 3. create a file named 'test1.xml' The new file is displayed with the default (text) file icon. 4. associate '*.xml' files to the ant editor in window>preferences>workbench>file associations 5. create a file named 'test2.xml' The new file is displayed with the ant file icon, test1.xml is still displayed with the default file icon.
Closing/re-opening the view solves the problem. Which view are you opening/closing? Navigator? Package Explorer? ... I tried with the Navigator and with the Package Explorer, the result is the same. This is a general problem with all navigator-like views, not just the Navigator. Would need some kind of notification from the editor registry that the file associations had changed. The relevant label providers would have to listen for changes, e.g. WorkbenchLabelProvider.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20031203
1. launch Eclipse on a new workspace 2. create a project 3. create a file named 'test1.xml' The new file is displayed with the default (text) file icon. 4. associate '*.xml' files to the ant editor in window>preferences>workbench>file associations 5. create a file named 'test2.xml' The new file is displayed with the ant file icon, test1.xml is still displayed with the default file icon.
Closing/re-opening the view solves the problem. Which view are you opening/closing? Navigator? Package Explorer? ... I tried with the Navigator and with the Package Explorer, the result is the same. This is a general problem with all navigator-like views, not just the Navigator. Would need some kind of notification from the editor registry that the file associations had changed. The relevant label providers would have to listen for changes, e.g. WorkbenchLabelProvider.

Bug.Summery: Zoom Out action is enabled although it doesn't do anything

Lines.Line: 1) Make your diagram big enough so that zooming to "Page" would require a zoom
level that is less than the minimum.
2) Set the zoom level to be the smallest possible from the drop-down combo
box.
3) At this point, the zoom out actions will be enabled.
4) However, clicking it won't do anything.

Bug.WithStack:
1) Make your diagram big enough so that zooming to "Page" would require a zoom level that is less than the minimum. 2) Set the zoom level to be the smallest possible from the drop-down combo box. 3) At this point, the zoom out actions will be enabled. 4) However, clicking it won't do anything.
This is because canZoomOut() -- which invokes getMinZoom() -- takes the "Page" zoom setting into account. However, when getPreviousZoomLevel() is invoked, it just returns the previous setting from the array of zoom levels, and ignores the "Page" zoom setting. Fixed. getMinZoom() does not take the "Page" setting into account. Separated primSetZoom() method -- the range check is done in setZoom(), but not in primSetZoom() -- out of setZoom(). Whenever one of the "Page" settings is selected, primSetZoom() is invoked instead of setZoom().
Bug.WithOutStack:
1) Make your diagram big enough so that zooming to "Page" would require a zoom level that is less than the minimum. 2) Set the zoom level to be the smallest possible from the drop-down combo box. 3) At this point, the zoom out actions will be enabled. 4) However, clicking it won't do anything.
This is because canZoomOut() -- which invokes getMinZoom() -- takes the "Page" zoom setting into account. However, when getPreviousZoomLevel() is invoked, it just returns the previous setting from the array of zoom levels, and ignores the "Page" zoom setting. Fixed. getMinZoom() does not take the "Page" setting into account. Separated primSetZoom() method -- the range check is done in setZoom(), but not in primSetZoom() -- out of setZoom(). Whenever one of the "Page" settings is selected, primSetZoom() is invoked instead of setZoom().

Bug.Summery: ZoomManager's "Page" settings cause erratic behavior
Bug.WithStack: Keep entering 1% in the zoom combo box and you will see that the diagram keeps shrinking a little by little. This is because the ZoomManager is interpreting that 1% as "Page," and shrinking the diagram accordingly. And since it's using the Figure's preferred size to calculate the zoom level, and because changing the zoom level changes its preferred size, when you enter 1% the next time, the new minimum zoom is slightly less than earlier. Set a UI multiplier, and you will see a lot more anomalies for this case. Simply choosing "Page" from the drop-down changes the zoom level four times, causing flickers on the screeng. Fixed. When setting the zoom level to be page, width, or height, the extra space to the right/bottom of the editor is not removed. Hence, at the "Page" setting, you can still have both scrollbars. We have decided that we are going to leave it like that. Changing status to fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: Keep entering 1% in the zoom combo box and you will see that the diagram keeps shrinking a little by little. This is because the ZoomManager is interpreting that 1% as "Page," and shrinking the diagram accordingly. And since it's using the Figure's preferred size to calculate the zoom level, and because changing the zoom level changes its preferred size, when you enter 1% the next time, the new minimum zoom is slightly less than earlier. Set a UI multiplier, and you will see a lot more anomalies for this case. Simply choosing "Page" from the drop-down changes the zoom level four times, causing flickers on the screeng. Fixed. When setting the zoom level to be page, width, or height, the extra space to the right/bottom of the editor is not removed. Hence, at the "Page" setting, you can still have both scrollbars. We have decided that we are going to leave it like that. Changing status to fixed.

Bug.Summery: NPE in LinkedNamesAssistProposal

Lines.Line: - LinkedEnvironment has to be explicitly installed now
- If the installation succeeds, the required listeners are installed, if not,
the environment does not get registered and no listeners are installed.
- An installed environment will uninstall itself properly
- Installing an environment will remove any other conflicting linked modes, if
forceInstall is used.

Bug.WithStack:
I20031203

The problem were linked mode infrastructures that were not set up cleanly and kept lying around.
- LinkedEnvironment has to be explicitly installed now - If the installation succeeds, the required listeners are installed, if not, the environment does not get registered and no listeners are installed. - An installed environment will uninstall itself properly - Installing an environment will remove any other conflicting linked modes, if forceInstall is used.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20031203
Sorry, no steps to reproduce but I found several instances of the following in my log:
fixed > 20031205
The problem were linked mode infrastructures that were not set up cleanly and kept lying around.
- LinkedEnvironment has to be explicitly installed now - If the installation succeeds, the required listeners are installed, if not, the environment does not get registered and no listeners are installed. - An installed environment will uninstall itself properly - Installing an environment will remove any other conflicting linked modes, if forceInstall is used.

Bug.Summery: Loop event name should be seen in event tree, if loop has a name
Bug.WithStack: Currently in the test execution event tree, the loop event labels is the generic 'loop'. This label should be the actual loop name, if the loop has a name associated with it. Bug.Summery: ClassCastException launching JUnit plugin tests
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20031202
Attempting to launch JDT Core test suites for Eclipse 2.1 self-hosting workspace running on Eclipse 3.0 SDK; I get the following exception:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 2 Dec 05, 2003 00:19:52.879 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Launch". !STACK 0 java.lang.ClassCastException at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.findPlugin (JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:285) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.addRequiredPlugins (JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:260) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.computeProgramArgu ments(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:172) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.createVMRunner (JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:103) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.launch (JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:61) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch (LaunchConfiguration.java:156) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch (DebugUIPlugin.java:739) at org.eclipse.debug.ui.DebugUITools.buildAndLaunch (DebugUITools.java:625) at org.eclipse.debug.ui.DebugUITools$3.run(DebugUITools.java:581) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:62) This bug prevents testing the 2.1.3 maintenance effort. Any workaround is welcome.
Please use 3.0M4 (i.e. a pre-RCP build) to test against a 2.1x platform until this bug and bug 47880 are fixed.
The class cast exception is an OSGi aftershock. However, even when it gets fixed, you would then run into a backward compatibility problem with the PDE Junit launcher (bug 47880).
Fixed. To verify, I ran AllJavaModelTests from the R_2_1 maintenance branch against a 2.1.2 platform, and 1588/1588 tests passed.

Bug.Summery: [rename] Create template method from existing code [refactoring]
Ant will not launch with an incomplete class path
Bug.WithStack:
Ant will not launch if the classpath for the project is incomplete. An example of when this is a problem is when you want to use Ant to generate part of your project.
I can reproduce this on a virgin Eclipse 3.0M5 build. However, I have another Eclipse 3.0M5 build which started life as a 3.0M2 build and has been upgraded with each new milestone drop. The upgraded installation doesn't have this problem.
The workaround is to use a command line to drive Ant to "bootstrap" the project; not quite as nice. Robert I am not quite grokking what you are doing...are you running Ant on the build.xml that you have auto-generated from the plugin.xml for your project?
What exactly do you mean "Ant will not launch"? Step by step details would be greatly appreciated. I have a manually created build.xml for my Java project. This has tasks in it which I want to create elements that will go onto my classpath. An example would be the task that goes and fetches the correct version of various third- party JAR files.
If my project is in clean state (e.g. checked out of CVS), these elements don't exist yet. I need to run Ant to get them.
If I try to run Ant from within the virgin Eclipse 3.0M5 installation, I get an error like this: ERROR: Launch: the archive: /<project>/lib/log4j.jar which is referenced by the classpath, does not exist
The "upgraded" Eclipse installation doesn't have this behaviour. This may be the result of setting an option that doesn't appear in the GUI anymore, but I'm not sure.
Once I run Ant from the command-line, the problem goes away (until I run the full-clean task which blows them all away again...)
To reproduce: * use a vanilla Eclipse 3.0M5 installation. * Create a project * Create a simple Ant script, with a Hello-World style task. * Add a JAR file to the project. * Add the Jar file to the project's class path. * Run ant script, verify it works. * Delete JAR file from filesystem. * Refresh project. * Verify the Java build error due to the incomplete classpath * Run ant script. * Note error in the Progess view.
In M5 the default behavior for new launch configurations is to run the build in a separate VM. This means that the classpath for the project is resolved before the build occurs (I am not sure this is required..needs more investigation).
The workaround for you is to specify that the Ant build occur in the same VM as Eclipse (see the Ant JRE tab for your Ant launch configuration) where the classpath resolution is not needed. This will give you the same behavior as in your "upgraded" Eclipse installation. Thanks Darin, that workaround does indeed work.
It would be very useful, however, to be able to launch Ant in a separate JVM, particuarly if an ANT_HOME outside of Eclipse is being used. Wow that was quick :-) I agree that this seems like an unnecessary restriction. I am looking into as we speak... The "Ant in a separate VM" launch mimics being a Java application launch. The AntLaunchDelegate was not setting a ISourceLocator for the launch, so JavaRuntime was happily providing the default Java source locator and therefore had to resolve the classpath for the project (and hit the missing JAR problem). Ant launches do not need the Java source locator.
Fixed in AntLaunchDelegate.
Please verify Luc. Verified. Please update the build notes, Darin S. *** Bug 48741 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 52173 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: Run/Debug As actions disabled with no selection
Bug.WithStack:
All of the Run/Debug As actions are disabled if you don't have a selection, as at startup. Not all shortcuts require a selection. In particular, the PDE Runtime Workbench shortcut requires no context.
The actions should either only be disabled for shortcuts that require a context or they should always be enabled and shortcuts that require a context can prompt the user when they're run. Should be considered in conjunction with run/debug context menu work (bug 18338) Marking as dup. Newer bug report has more dialoge.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 53722 ***

Bug.Summery: Assert statement parens causes refactoring to... do nothing
Bug.WithStack:
The following statement (where stype is a String): assert (stype.length()>0); Causes any refactorings on the menu to simply do nothing. No error or anything. Removing the (unnecessary) parens makes refactorings work again.
As a secondary bug, if refactorings are not going to happen for whatever reason, there should at least be an error message. (I had thought that my Eclipse setup was messed up and causing refactoring to fail, so I reinstalled Eclipse, restored settings which I'd been fiddling with, etc... until I finally realized that the problem was only with one source file, and not a session-wide problem.) refactoring is jdt-ui.
John, which compiler compilance settings are you using? 1.4, default compliance settings. All four options in Classfile Generation are checked.
There are two issues here:
- if you use the assert feature the compliance level must be set to 1.4 and and Generated .class files compatibility and source compatibility must be set to 1.4. Disallow identifiers... must be set to Error.
- if you don't set this, the CU will contain an error that method assert isn't know. This might some refactoring to fail. However I tested it with I20031203 and most of them worked.
Closing as works for me in 3.0 stream. John please reopen if I am missing something.

Bug.Summery: Breakpoint in renamed project leads to exception

Lines.Line: 1. Create a simple java project with one class and a main method.
2. Set a breakpoint in the main method.
3. Create a launch configuration of type application
4. debug and observe how the breakpoint is hit correctly
5. refactor the project's name.
6. Go into the debug debug perspective.
There will be exceptions in the .log file or ErrorLog window.
Created attachment 7069
Logfile containing exceptions

Bug.WithStack:
I ran into this originally in a more elaborate plugin development scenario on 2.1.1. However I can reproduce it with 3.0 M5 as well. Here are the steps: 1. Create a simple java project with one class and a main method. 2. Set a breakpoint in the main method. 3. Create a launch configuration of type application 4. debug and observe how the breakpoint is hit correctly 5. refactor the project's name. 6. Go into the debug debug perspective. There will be exceptions in the .log file or ErrorLog window. Created attachment 7069 Logfile containing exceptions
This is from the original situation, repeated twice. Could not reproduce problem. It looks like the breakpoints view was attempting to render a breakpoint that no longer exists. When I try this, the breakpoint is removed as expected (when a project is renamed). We intend to improve this with refactoring support in 3.0, such that the breakpoint remains.
However, I did remove unecessary logging of exceptions from BreakpointUtils and JDIModelPresentation. Please verify, Darin (S). I can reproduce the problem on 20031209..the breakpoint is not removed. With the changes nothing is logged to the Error Log but I am now left with a breakpoint that has as a label "<not responding>". Investigating. Good - that you can reproduce it (and that label is expected in the case of a missing type). However, the breakpoint should get deleted. There resource change listener which leads to the element changed notification is for post change. We are only post auto build. So we get told about the Java types that have been deleted before the auto build has completed and before we have loading the breakpoints for the project that has just opened (and has the marker with the old type handle). The problem is with the project rename. The change notification has changed somehow. When you rename a single compilation unit, breakpoints are cleaned up fine (i.e. auto-deleted). The same used to happen with project renames. I could not find a simple fix for M6.
The side effect is that you have to manually delete the breakpoints yourself (from the breakpoints view). Marking as a dup since this will just be replaced by refactoring support, rather than a fix (see bug 7552).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 7552 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
I ran into this originally in a more elaborate plugin development scenario on 2.1.1. However I can reproduce it with 3.0 M5 as well. Here are the steps: 1. Create a launch configuration of type application 4. debug and observe how the breakpoint is hit correctly 5. refactor the project's name. 6. Go into the debug debug perspective. There will be exceptions in the .log file or ErrorLog window. Created attachment 7069 Logfile containing exceptions

When I try this, the breakpoint is removed as expected (when a project is renamed). We intend to improve this with refactoring support in 3.0, such that the breakpoint remains.

With the changes nothing is logged to the Error Log but I am now left with a breakpoint that has as a label "<not responding>". Investigating. The same used to happen with project renames. I could not find a simple fix for M6.
The side effect is that you have to manually delete the breakpoints yourself (from the breakpoints view). Marking as a dup since this will just be replaced by refactoring support, rather than a fix (see bug 7552).

Bug.Summery: Code assistance and format for ambiguous inner Java class name

source_code.code: /** * Feature Missing in Eclispe M5: * * I like to write code like as noted below, and it seams that eclispe * handling of ambigouse inner class names is suboptimal during codeassistance. * And the code formater has problems with disambigouated names. * Note: The exampe below is optimzed for shortness and that make it look a * little bit stupid, but "real world" exmples are much longer .. . */
public static final class Problem extends Exception { }

/** * ... and as a result I have many inner classes with the names * "Problem", "Factory" or "Item". * Now I Use code completation to procduce method stubs and got errors * as note in the method comments below. * I use "Automatically add import instead of qualified name" in * Window > Preferences > Java > Editor > Code Assist: */

/** * Note: There are more erros not noted here, you have to rewrite this example * to see all my struggles * Suggestion: * [1] In "Window > Preferences > Java > Editor > Code Assist" add an * flag "Don't import inner classes" or "Import only toplevel classes" * (and of course implemented it). * [2] Don't break disambigouated names above the line end during code format. * By the way: If you don't like "my style" the code generator has still a * problem becuse it producess buggy code. * So you may change this feature request to an bug report. * * Kind regards * * mle@neze.de **/

Bug.Summery: Description variables are not resolved
Bug.WithStack:
Variables listed between the description tags in a site.xml do not resolve. For example, if you have the following code in the site.xml (assuming it's wrapped in a category-def element tag):
<description>%mydesc</description>
And you have the following in your site.properties:
mydesc=Can you see me?
When you create a bookmark to this site.xml and click on the category, you will see the following in the right hand view pane: %mydesc. Expected behavior is to see the string "Can you see me?". In 3.0 the site description is not used any more, so the bug becomes invalid (it was a valid bug in 2.1.x)
Bug.WithOutStack:
Variables listed between the description tags in a site.xml do not resolve. For example, if you have the following code in the site.xml (assuming it's wrapped in a category-def element tag):
<description>%mydesc</description>
And you have the following in your site.properties:
mydesc=Can you see me?
When you create a bookmark to this site.xml and click on the category, you will see the following in the right hand view pane: %mydesc. Expected behavior is to see the string "Can you see me?". In 3.0 the site description is not used any more, so the bug becomes invalid (it was a valid bug in 2.1.x)

Bug.Summery: setEditable() method doesn't work
Bug.WithStack:
The following solution is used to make the editor readonly or locking it so that no one can write in it.
I am using the following method in JavaEditor example that is extending CompilationUnitEditor.
public void setEditable(boolean editable) { ISourceViewer viewer = getSourceViewer(); if (viewer != null) { viewer.setEditable(editable); } }
this didn't work and then I got another hack from Andrew about getting the sourceviewer after the creation of the editor.I do get the viewer throught that but I still can't get the seteditable method do any work.I used the following way of getting the SourceViewer() .
IWorkbench workbench = PlatformUI.getWorkbench(); IWorkbenchWindow window = workbench.getActiveWorkbenchWindow(); workbench.getActiveWorkbenchWindow(); IWorkbenchPage page = window.getActivePage(); IEditorPart part = page.getActiveEditor();
if (part instanceof CompilationUnitEditor) { CompilationUnitEditor editor = (CompilationUnitEditor)part; ITextViewer viewer = (ITextViewer)editor.getAdapter(ITextOperationTarget.class); }
when I call viewer.setEditable() here after the creation of the editor through a button nothing happens. There are couple of things that I have read about it. Frist how am I sure if the getActiveEditor does get me the editor I am typing on.If I use getSite() the above doesn't let me use it,or gives me a NullPointerException. Secondly everywhere in the archives I have read that everyone is calling getSourceViewer().setEditable(); But in my case I can't call that.
I think lately Jared had the same problem of gettiing a Null value when he use to call getActiveEditor where I think you reaplied that in 3.0 getSite and getPage() should be used.
I am using 2.1 right now as I can't use 3.0 as I have to do a lot of changes. *** Bug 48134 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This PR describes two problems (one with setEditable and one with getActiveEditor). This PR will only handle setEditable as outlined by the summary. Please file a bug against Platform UI if you think there's a bug in getActiveEditor.
>The following solution is used to make the editor readonly or locking it so >that no one can write in it. Note: This might not do the trick if some other action can change the underlying document.
I verified that the methods work as designed. What happens is the following: The viewer gets into read-only state and later on the editor framework updates the state again to true because it is a file editor and the read-only state depends on the file's read-only state.

Secondly everywhere in the archives I have read that everyone is calling getSourceViewer().setEditable(); But in my case I can't call that.
I think lately Jared had the same problem of gettiing a Null value when he use to call getActiveEditor where I think you reaplied that in 3.0 getSite and getPage() should be used.
I am using 2.1 right now as I can't use 3.0 as I have to do a lot of changes. *** Bug 48134 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This PR describes two problems (one with setEditable and one with getActiveEditor). This PR will only handle setEditable as outlined by the summary. Please file a bug against Platform UI if you think there's a bug in getActiveEditor.
>The following solution is used to make the editor readonly or locking it so >that no one can write in it. Note: This might not do the trick if some other action can change the underlying document.
I verified that the methods work as designed. What happens is the following: The viewer gets into read-only state and later on the editor framework updates the state again to true because it is a file editor and the read-only state depends on the file's read-only state.

Bug.Summery: Make HTMLTextPresenter public
Bug.WithStack:
HTMLTextPresenter is an internal class. This presenter has intelligent tooltip placement and text shortening. It can interpret some basic HTML tags like boldface font. So it makes use to make the class public API so that others do not need to implement the same functionality again. Eclipse 3.0 contains a SWT browser widget which allows you to render full HTML. So there is no need to make HTMLPresenter API. Reopening to correctly dipsose.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 46549 ***

Bug.Summery: CVS metafiles always have unix EOL
Bug.WithStack:
(Third time -- at least I copied the Description pane text this time! Thank you bugzilla.)
Ok, second time typing this in because I got an error submitting it the first time and Bugzilla told me to hit the Back button and fix it and lost all the data on the form when I did (nice). This will be shorter due to my RSI.
Our CVS server is running on an OS X Machine (10.2.6)
When checking out a project from CVS on Windows, it is checked out as a Unix project. If you try to perform any CVS actions on the checked out project using Tortoise CVS, you are shown an error message that tells you did. I had typed in the whole message last time but cannot this time (you cannot copy/paste the error message in the dialog -- nice -- they really think of us folk with RSI when designing apps).
Problems due to this: Cannot diff (compare) files in Eclipse. Cannot use checked out project with TortoiseCVS.
Seen on WinXP and Windows 2000. "that tells you did" should be "that tells you this" Btw, we are using extssh. Although the problem still appears with open source projects such as Ant and Jetspeed, the compare function in Eclipse works with files in those projects, leading me to believe that the two things are not related. Those projects, when checked out, are also checked out as Unix on Windows. Update: The issue is *not* with the built-in extssh -- the same thing happens (a Unix checkout is performed on Windows) when using exactly the same ext ssh as TortoiseCVS.
When TortoiseCVS is used to checkout the same project, however, it is correctly checked out for Windows. When I check out files on windows, they are checked out in windows format (i.e. CRLF linefeeds). I noticed that the meta files that are saved by Eclispe use Unix line endings (e.g. CVSROOT/Entries). Perhaps this is a problem for Tortoise. Can you verify this (i.e. open the CVS/Entries file in Notepad from the Windows exploere and see what the line endings are for Eclipse and Tortoise). Update: The issue with the diff/compares was completely unrelated. We were running an unsupported version of CVS (1.10). Upgrading it got rid of that issue.
However, the main problem remains.
More info: http://www.flashant.org/index.php?m=200312#10 Hi Michael, I see the problem with the meta files, yes. I manually altered them to match a repository checked out in Tortoise and still got the warning from Tortoise.
Apparently, it is only a warning though and you can disable it from Preferences -> Advanced -> Check not Unix sandbox.
I don't know, however, if this will have any ill effects if used with the meta files saved by Eclipse. So the problem is the CVS/Entries file. Does this prevent Tortoise from working or does it just give you a warning? I suspect it's the later. Ignoe my last question. I added it after your last post but before I saw it. I suspect you will not have problems as Eclipse will handle either line ending. I suspect Tortoise will as well. Np, I did the same with your last post :) Tortoise appears to be handling it but just in case I think we'll lay off mixing the two whenever possible. Now that we have the compare issue solved, we don't really need to use Tortoise alongside Eclipse. Good to know that it's assigned to be fixed, though. Thanks! :) Post 3.0 This was fixed in 3.0

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] Public API for ContainerCheckedTreeViewer, ResourceTreeAndListGroup
Bug.WithStack:
These are very useful classes. They are good for use in wizards. From my point of view, there is no alternative for these APIs. Especially ResourceTreeAndListGroup is used by Eclipse in the following Export Wizards: file, jar, JavaDoc, and zip. The ContainerCheckedTreeViewer class provides the standard behavior of placing a grayed checkbox on a parent container which has some but not all of its children checked and a solid check on a container that has all its children checked. This is the behavior we want in wizards for exporting resources to a remote server (FTP or WebDAV). Unfortunately, the class is internal. Is there API to give this checking behavior that I missed? If not and this is a behavior that we want to advocate, could we consider making the class API (and save me from copying it;-)? *** Bug 50357 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Not planned for 3.0 Reopening now that 3.0 has shipped any news on this? I have promoted ContainerCheckedTreeViewer to API in org.eclipse.ui.dialogs. I am not going to promote ResourceTreeAndListGroup at this time as no one uses it and it could do with some work. If you still want me to promote ResourceTreeAndListGroup please log a seperate bug report as we need to track the completed work in this one.
Adding Dejan as it looks like update copies this.
I will delete this once Team and JDT have update thier references.
Fixed in build >20050315 I have released the changes to Team and RelEng to HEAD. Did you inform JDT of the change directly (I don't see them on the CC list)? Adding Wassim - I am sure PDE has at least one checkbox tree that exhibits this behaviour. Verified in 20050330
Also verified that there are no more internal references.
Logged by 89591 to delete this in M7 Verified in 20050330

Bug.Summery: Plugin import - wizard does not consider target platform refresh

Lines.Line: - open the file import plug-in wizard
- configured the target platform there to point at a 2.1.2 SDK install
- select import as binary
- press NEXT
- in the list of available plug-ins, org.eclipse.pde.junit isn't available
(ok as it is not part of the 2.1 delivery)
- hit BACK, keep import wizard up,
- outside Eclipse, expand the missing plug-in into the 2.1.2 install
- back inside Eclipse, import wizard is still up, click on target platform
button
- in target platform wizard, press RELOAD
- observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is listed, press OK
- back into import wizard, press NEXT
- observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is NOT listed
(you have to close and reopen the wizard so as to see it)
Fixed.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20031202
I am developping for Eclipse 2.1 using a self-hosting 2.1 workspace on top of Eclipse SDK 3.0. I wanted to launch Eclipse 2.1 as a runtime workbench so as to run some test suites (due to bug 48125); and thus remembered I needed to import an extra plug-in: org.eclipse.pde.junit.
In order to do so, I did the following: - open the file import plug-in wizard - configured the target platform there to point at a 2.1.2 SDK install - select import as binary - press NEXT - in the list of available plug-ins, org.eclipse.pde.junit isn't available (ok as it is not part of the 2.1 delivery) - hit BACK, keep import wizard up, - outside Eclipse, expand the missing plug-in into the 2.1.2 install - back inside Eclipse, import wizard is still up, click on target platform button - in target platform wizard, press RELOAD - observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is listed, press OK - back into import wizard, press NEXT - observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is NOT listed (you have to close and reopen the wizard so as to see it) Fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20031202
I am developping for Eclipse 2.1 using a self-hosting 2.1 workspace on top of Eclipse SDK 3.0. I wanted to launch Eclipse 2.1 as a runtime workbench so as to run some test suites (due to bug 48125); and thus remembered I needed to import an extra plug-in: org.eclipse.pde.junit.
In order to do so, I did the following: - open the file import plug-in wizard - configured the target platform there to point at a 2.1.2 SDK install - select import as binary - press NEXT - in the list of available plug-ins, org.eclipse.pde.junit isn't available (ok as it is not part of the 2.1 delivery) - hit BACK, keep import wizard up, - outside Eclipse, expand the missing plug-in into the 2.1.2 install - back inside Eclipse, import wizard is still up, click on target platform button - in target platform wizard, press RELOAD - observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is listed, press OK - back into import wizard, press NEXT - observe that org.eclipse.pde.junit is NOT listed (you have to close and reopen the wizard so as to see it) Fixed.

Bug.Summery: [DCR] Request for new Option for the Java compiler: "Warning in Writable File"
Bug.WithStack:
The "Options for the Java compiler" can set to Error, Warning or Ignore. There should be another Option "Warning in Writable File".
Backround: We work on a large projekt with several MByte Java-Source. There are thousands of non-critical Problems like Problems in Javadoc Tags, Unused Imports, Unnecessary casts... This could be corrected, if and only if the file is checked out (writable) because of another problem. It would help to limit these warnings to writable files. Post 3.0 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Synchronizing RTF files always reports same

Lines.Line: - The Eclipse properties for the local file shows the correct, new date.
- In CVS there is only the initial version, with correct (old) date.
- The local document is really different from what's in the repository.
- The document is checked in as binary.
Have you tried refreshing Eclipse to detect that a file outside the workspace
has changed? In the Navigator select the file and run "Refresh" from the
context menu.
We plan on improving this experience in Eclipse see Bug 36962.

Bug.WithStack:
I have some MS Word RTF documents in my project. I have added the documents successfully to the projects CVS module. However, now that I have changed the documents with Word (started from Eclipse), Synchronize believes no commit is necessary. It consistently reports no changes and I am not able to commit the changed version to the repository. Even when I just "commit" without synchrinizing first, nothing happens.
Things I checked:
- The Eclipse properties for the local file shows the correct, new date. - In CVS there is only the initial version, with correct (old) date. - The local document is really different from what's in the repository. - The document is checked in as binary. Have you tried refreshing Eclipse to detect that a file outside the workspace has changed? In the Navigator select the file and run "Refresh" from the context menu. We plan on improving this experience in Eclipse see Bug 36962.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I have some MS Word RTF documents in my project. I have added the documents successfully to the projects CVS module. However, now that I have changed the documents with Word (started from Eclipse), Synchronize believes no commit is necessary. It consistently reports no changes and I am not able to commit the changed version to the repository. Even when I just "commit" without synchrinizing first, nothing happens.
Things I checked:
- The Eclipse properties for the local file shows the correct, new date. - In CVS there is only the initial version, with correct (old) date. - The local document is really different from what's in the repository. - The document is checked in as binary. Have you tried refreshing Eclipse to detect that a file outside the workspace has changed? In the Navigator select the file and run "Refresh" from the context menu. We plan on improving this experience in Eclipse see Bug 36962.

Bug.Summery: Extension name not properly set when read from the cache
Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.jdt.core.javabuilder does not have a label Created attachment 7074 no label
Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200312030800 Moving to JDT/Debug for further investigation. I observed this behavior as well, but we do define a label in our plugin.xml/plugin.properties.
Any clue ? Moving to platform ant (external tools support) I am not able to reproduce the problem. Is this for all of your projects? Is the label always missing? Any particular test case? Thanks. I see the same problem. In the builders properties page of org.eclipse.ant.core, only 'Built Ant Support JAR' has a label, the other 3 builders have no label.
I see it too (or rather, do not see labels). OK...I am missing labels in my host but not in my runtime-workbench target? Something strange afoot... Pascal the labels that are missing are generated using the code in BuilderPropertyPage.getBuildName(String builderID): ---- IExtension extension = Platform.getPluginRegistry().getExtension (ResourcesPlugin.PI_RESOURCES, ResourcesPlugin.PT_BUILDERS, builderID);
String builderName; if (extension != null) { builderName = extension.getLabel(); } else { builderName = MessageFormat.format(ExternalToolsUIMessages.getString ("BuilderPropertyPage.missingBuilder"), new Object[] { builderID }); //$NON- NLS-1$ } return builderName; ---------
It would appear that in the host workspace, extension.getLabel() is returning an empty string, whereas in a PDE runtime-workbench the correct label of the extension is returned. Is this a known issue? This sounds like a runtime issue... Moving to equinox-general and renaming.
There were several problems. First some fields were not written by the cache writer and second some translation were not saved.
This is all fixed and released in HEAD.
*** Bug 44819 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** verified in 200403100800
Bug.WithOutStack:
org.eclipse.jdt.core.javabuilder does not have a label Created attachment 7074 no label
Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200312030800 Moving to JDT/Debug for further investigation. I observed this behavior as well, but we do define a label in our plugin.xml/plugin.properties.
Any clue ? Moving to platform ant (external tools support) I am not able to reproduce the problem. Is this for all of your projects? Is the label always missing? Any particular test case? Thanks. I see the same problem. In the builders properties page of org.eclipse.ant.core, only 'Built Ant Support JAR' has a label, the other 3 builders have no label.
I see it too (or rather, do not see labels). OK...I am missing labels in my host but not in my runtime-workbench target? Something strange afoot... Pascal the labels that are missing are generated using the code in BuilderPropertyPage.getBuildName(String builderID): ---- IExtension extension = Platform.getPluginRegistry().getExtension (ResourcesPlugin.PI_RESOURCES, ResourcesPlugin.PT_BUILDERS, builderID);
String builderName; if (extension != null) { builderName = extension.getLabel(); } else { builderName = MessageFormat.format(ExternalToolsUIMessages.getString ("BuilderPropertyPage.missingBuilder"), new Object[] { builderID }); //$NON- NLS-1$ } return builderName; ---------
It would appear that in the host workspace, extension.getLabel() is returning an empty string, whereas in a PDE runtime-workbench the correct label of the extension is returned. Is this a known issue? This sounds like a runtime issue... Moving to equinox-general and renaming.
There were several problems. First some fields were not written by the cache writer and second some translation were not saved.
This is all fixed and released in HEAD.

Bug.Summery: validate Java Applet Parameters
Bug.WithStack:
Run/Run...
Select "Java Applet"
New
Parameters tab
Both the Width and Height TA should valdidate that the user entered an integer value > 0 and should display an appropriate error message if not. We had code to validate this input as it was entered, but we were blowing up before we got to the validation. The isValid() method was already written to handle a NumberFormatException and post an error message, but the performApply() method wasn't. It was blowing up with a number format exception, which stopped the execution from proceeding to the isValid() call.
Fixed in AppletParametersTab. Please verify, DarinS. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Run/Run...
Select "Java Applet"
New
Parameters tab
Both the Width and Height TA should valdidate that the user entered an integer value > 0 and should display an appropriate error message if not. We had code to validate this input as it was entered, but we were blowing up before we got to the validation. The isValid() method was already written to handle a NumberFormatException and post an error message, but the performApply() method wasn't. It was blowing up with a number format exception, which stopped the execution from proceeding to the isValid() call.
Fixed in AppletParametersTab. Please verify, DarinS. Verified.

Bug.Summery: NPE invoking quickfix on class [quick fix]
Add ability to persist objects for a plugin / project
Bug.WithStack:
Often plugins need to maintain state at plugin level or per project. Projects allow to save project properties - but it's only possible to save strings there. Because I think that saving state is a common task for most plugins, I'd appreciate if there's a possibility to save objects for a plugin/project without having to implement the persistence mechanism. E.g. the platform could support the XML (de-)serialization of objects. Plugins can obtain a per-project private metadata area with IProject.getPluginWorkingLocation. Yes, I know, but I think it would be useful to have a framework service for persisting objects instead of implementing a persistence service in every plugin. JDK 1.4 already includes JAXP APIs for (de)serialization of XML. I'm going to mark this as a dup of the user settings plan item, which may include API for storing richer per-project settings.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36965 ***

Bug.Summery: Refresh on projects / packages lost its magic

Lines.Line: - Create empty Java Project
- Create new class "Test" with "main" method
- Create new class "MyClass" (note that both files are now open)
- Add inside "main":
- Obvious error appears
- Close file "MyClass.java"
- Open file "MyClass.java" in external editor (e.g. Notepad)
- Add new constructor:
- Save the file
- Do the "Project Refresh"
- Package tree may be updated correctly, but...
- ... error in "Test.java" is still red-underlined

Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse Platform Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200311211210
"Project refresh" and "Package refresh" does not see changes in source files made outside the Eclipse.
Exact way to reproduce bug: - Create empty Java Project - Create new class "Test" with "main" method - Create new class "MyClass" (note that both files are now open) - Add inside "main": MyClass object = new MyClass("test"); - Obvious error appears - Close file "MyClass.java" - Open file "MyClass.java" in external editor (e.g. Notepad) - Add new constructor: MyClass(String s) { } - Save the file - Do the "Project Refresh" - Package tree may be updated correctly, but... - ... error in "Test.java" is still red-underlined
Probably linked issue: Sometimes after deleting a class from project (and simultaneously from disk!), it still appears in the package tree.
Such behaviour is unique to Eclipse 3.0M5 (it was NOT in 3.0M4)
I work with external UML tool to generate skeleton code for classes. So I need to update some classes outside the Eclipse, or possibly add some new classes. While everything was fine in Eclipse 3.0M4, something is broken in 3.0M5. I tested the above scenario in I20031216 (M6 candidate) and wasn't able to reproduce. Please not that temporary errors only go away in the editor after giving focus to the editor.
Can you please retest it again using M6 and reopen if the problem still exists?
