Bug.Summery: Bug in jar exporting [jarcreation]

Lines.Line: 1. export eclipse project to jar file placed in this project directory
2. refresh project directory
3. try to export this project again. On top of window "JAR Packaged
Specification" you'll see error message: "The JAR file can not be packaged into
itself"
4. Uncheck with mouse clicking jar file created in 1. - the message will
disapear, it works fine
5. But check it again with mouse click and uncheck with keyboard, pressing
SPACE. The error message will not disapear and you'll still can't make export!

Bug.WithStack:
To produce bug: 1. export eclipse project to jar file placed in this project directory 2. refresh project directory 3. try to export this project again. On top of window "JAR Packaged Specification" you'll see error message: "The JAR file can not be packaged into itself" 4. Uncheck with mouse clicking jar file created in 1. - the message will disapear, it works fine 5. But check it again with mouse click and uncheck with keyboard, pressing SPACE. The error message will not disapear and you'll still can't make export!
You'll get different result when using mouse and different when using keyboard.
Kuba Królikowski Move to JDT/UI. They handle jar export. Works for me using R3.2 or newer.
Bug.WithOutStack:
To produce bug: 1. export eclipse project to jar file placed in this project directory 2. refresh project directory 3. try to export this project again. Uncheck with mouse clicking jar file created in 1. - the message will disapear, it works fine 5. But check it again with mouse click and uncheck with keyboard, pressing SPACE. The error message will not disapear and you'll still can't make export!
You'll get different result when using mouse and different when using keyboard.
Kuba Królikowski Move to JDT/UI. They handle jar export. Works for me using R3.2 or newer.

Bug.Summery: Merge Optimizations

Lines.Line: 1) Support import and export of merge subscriber state
2) When a file is Marked as merged, remember the merged revision with the
file. The next time that file is merged (i.e. when the remote changed), we can
use the remebered revision as the base when the file is shown in a compare
view. This could greatly simplify the manual merge process.
3) When the file content compare determines that two files are equal (although
theire revisions differ), the revision number should be remembered as well in
case future merges are required.
4) There is no need to refresh the base of a merge subscriber
For point 1, this is what cvs nt provides via a special file it creates for
merges to remember. This would be really cool. Maybe the file should always be
created or the user prompted to create it when starting a merge?

Bug.WithStack:
Now that we have ongoing merges, we should consider the following optimizations:
1) Support import and export of merge subscriber state
2) When a file is Marked as merged, remember the merged revision with the file. The next time that file is merged (i.e. when the remote changed), we can use the remebered revision as the base when the file is shown in a compare view. This could greatly simplify the manual merge process.
3) When the file content compare determines that two files are equal (although theire revisions differ), the revision number should be remembered as well in case future merges are required.
4) There is no need to refresh the base of a merge subscriber For point 1, this is what cvs nt provides via a special file it creates for merges to remember. This would be really cool. Maybe the file should always be created or the user prompted to create it when starting a merge?
I have done steps 2, 3 and 4. All that remains is the persistance of the merge state. Would be cool, but not necessary for 3.0. Post 3.0 Won't fix.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Now that we have ongoing merges, we should consider the following optimizations:
1) Support import and export of merge subscriber state
2) When a file is Marked as merged, remember the merged revision with the file. The next time that file is merged (i.e. when the remote changed), we can use the remebered revision as the base when the file is shown in a compare view. This could greatly simplify the manual merge process.
3) When the file content compare determines that two files are equal (although theire revisions differ), the revision number should be remembered as well in case future merges are required.
4) There is no need to refresh the base of a merge subscriber For point 1, this is what cvs nt provides via a special file it creates for merges to remember. This would be really cool. Maybe the file should always be created or the user prompted to create it when starting a merge?
I have done steps 2, 3 and 4. All that remains is the persistance of the merge state. Would be cool, but not necessary for 3.0. Post 3.0 Won't fix.

Bug.Summery: [browser] no more handles exception on linux gtk rh9

Lines.Line: -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 6583 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-awt-gtk-
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 14103 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-gnome-gtk-
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 190447 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-gtk-3034.so
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 56996 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-mozilla-gtk-
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 257181 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-pi-gtk-

Bug.WithStack:
From Sheldon:
Chris, fyi, I tried again last night on my home PC (yet another machine) which is running RH9 and I still get the same problems using the 12-02 integration driver. I completely uninstalled Mozilla 1.4 packages and installed the three RPMS without any dependency problems or complaints, could serve from Mozilla 1.5, had the directories created and the gre.conf file created. Still I got the "no more handles" exception, identical to what I sent you previously running on RH8. Hi Sheldon, A few questions: which build of SWT are you using? Are you using the GTK SWT distribution? Can you confirm a standalone (not a plugin) SWT application fail in the same way for you (e.g. http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/snippits/snippet136.txt
I'm experiencing the same problem trying to instantiate a Browser component running on Debian (Sid). The code works fine on Win XP.
The SWT exception is thrown in the ctor of org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser. Here's the code that causes the error:
try { Library.loadLibrary ("swt-mozilla"); //$NON-NLS-1$ } catch (UnsatisfiedLinkError e) { dispose(); SWT.error(SWT.ERROR_NO_HANDLES); // <- this happens }
Needles to say that the error constant should be a different one. I still have no idea what actually causes the error.
I've got Mozilla 1.5 installed. The shared object set-mozilla is in my path exactly like the other swt shared objects.
I noticed that the GRE config file was not part of my installation so I made my own:
thofmann@knippix:~$ cat /etc/gre gre.conf grep-dctrl.rc thofmann@knippix:~$ cat /etc/gre.conf 1.5 GRE_PATH=/usr/lib/mozilla
I don't think this is the problem though. I'm using the following parameters to start my app:
-Djava.library.path="/opt/eclipse 3/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/:/usr/lib/mozilla/"
The call to Library.loadLibrary tries to load a lib called swt-mozilla-gtk- 3034, which is fine since I'm working with the Milestone 6 build.
String newName = name + "-" + platform + "-" + version; //$NON- NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ System.loadLibrary (newName);
Now this call fails. This is what my SOs look like:
thofmann@knippix:~$ ll "/opt/eclipse 3/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86" insgesamt 576 -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 43319 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-atk-gtk- 3034.so -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 6583 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-awt-gtk- 3034.so -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 14103 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-gnome-gtk- 3034.so -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 190447 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-gtk-3034.so -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 56996 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-mozilla-gtk- 3034.so -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 257181 2003-12-19 02:26 libswt-pi-gtk- 3034.so
I'm not sure if trying to load swt-mozilla-gtk-3034 should actually load swt- mozilla-gtk-3034.so. Is this correct? Is lib prefixed and .so suffixed by the VM?
I found out that the call to Library.loadLibrary tries to load a different lib in case the first System.loadLibrary call fails. That's why the original (the first one) exception is not thrown to the caller.
try { String newName = name + "-" + platform + "-" + version; //$NON- NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ System.loadLibrary (newName); return; } catch (UnsatisfiedLinkError e1) { try { String newName = name + "-" + platform; //$NON-NLS-1$ System.loadLibrary (newName); return; } catch (UnsatisfiedLinkError e2) { throw e1; } }
A little test case sheds some light on the problem:
public class BrowserLoadingTest {
public static void main(String[] args) { try { System.loadLibrary("swt-mozilla-gtk-3034"); } catch(UnsatisfiedLinkError e) { System.out.println("Caught: " + e); } } }
Setting the same lib path again executing this test gives me:
Caught: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /opt/eclipse 3/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3034.so: libxpcom.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory^
So the answer to my question above about prefixing with "lib" seems to be that this is how it must be.
So what about libxpcom.so?
thofmann@knippix:~$ ll /usr/lib/mozilla insgesamt 1572 drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 2003-12-01 19:53 chrome drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 16384 2003-12-01 19:53 components drwxr-xr-x 7 root root 4096 2003-07-25 00:49 defaults drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 2003-07-25 00:49 ipc lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 10 2003-12-01 19:52 libmozz.so - > ../libz.so -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 178572 2003-11-07 05:51 libnssckbi.so -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 476 2003-11-07 05:17 libsoftokn3.chk -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 957200 2003-11-07 05:51 libxpcom.so
So there it is. I notice that the so is not executable. Changing it using chmod a+x does not help. Closing this PR on the assumption that it is caused by an unsupported build of Mozilla: the SWT Browser widget on Linux does not work with Mozilla 1.5 GTK1.2 . A build of Mozilla using GTK2 is required.
See the SWT FAQ for info on this Mozilla build: - Which version of Mozilla do I need to install to run the SWT Browser on Linux GTK (RedHat 9 users) http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/faq.html#mozillaredhat
- Which version of Mozilla do I need to install to run the SWT Browser on Linux GTK (non RedHat 9 users) http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/faq.html#mozillanonredhat

Bug.Summery: Class ref checking doesn't understand arguments
Bug.WithStack:
build I20031121
In the spec for IExecutableExtension, it describes two ways in which an extension with a class attribute can pass arguments to the new instance. One of the ways is to append an argument string to the class name, using ':' as as separator.
I'm in the process of changing one of our tests to use this mechanism. We were previously using a separate "menuType" attribute which was not in the schema, so this was getting reported as a compile-time error (we run with all the PDE compiler checks set to Error).
The extension in question previously looked like: <view name="Action Filter Test View 1" menuType="static" icon="icons\view.gif" class="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.ListView" id="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.IActionFilterTest1"> </view>
It now looks like: <view name="Action Filter Test View 1" icon="icons\view.gif" class="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.ListView:-staticMenu" id="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.IActionFilterTest1"> </view>
PDE currently gives an error for this case: Referenced class 'org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.ListView:-staticMenu' in attribute 'class' cannot be found.
PDE should strip off any arguments before trying to resolve the class.
IExecutableExtension also describes another way of specifying arguments. You can convert the class-bearing attribute to a separate sub-element of the same name, with sub-sub-elements for arguments. For example, I could specify something like:
<view name="Action Filter Test View 1" icon="icons\view.gif" id="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.IActionFilterTest1"> <class class="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.ListView" <parameter name="menuType" value="static"> </class> </view>
Note that the element name is whatever the class-bearing attribute name was. In this case it happens to be "class", but it could have been something else, e.g. "run".
PDE should handle this case as well, without requiring that the schema for each extension point declares a subelement corresponding to the class-bearing attribute. I had a couple of syntax errors in the last example above. It should have been:
<view name="Action Filter Test View 1" icon="icons\view.gif" id="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.IActionFilterTest1"> <class class="org.eclipse.ui.tests.api.ListView"> <parameter name="menuType" value="static"/> </class> </view>
This currently generates several PDE errors complaining about missing a required attribute, and unknown <class> and <parameter> subelements.
Fixed. See bug 79184 for a request for additional checking.
Bug.WithOutStack:
build I20031121
In the spec for IExecutableExtension, it describes two ways in which an extension with a class attribute can pass arguments to the new instance. One of the ways is to append an argument string to the class name, using ':' as as separator.
I'm in the process of changing one of our tests to use this mechanism. We were previously using a separate "menuType" attribute which was not in the schema, so this was getting reported as a compile-time error (we run with all the PDE compiler checks set to Error).

Bug.Summery: Tooling to find plugins for a given resource
Bug.WithStack:
When authoring many of our various *.xml files a content developer/configurer needs to provide plugin-ids and class names. An example of this is hooking in actions to a cheat sheet.
However, once you have found a class that performs your desired action, there is no easy way to figure out what plug-in that class lives in. This is particularly true for binary projects.
This makes doing relativly easy user level things, like creating a cheat sheet, very, very difficult.
I believe there is a big need for tooling to help a user do this. providing assistance for cheatsheet authoring will be covered in bug 146988
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 146988 ***

Bug.Summery: [misc] Source not found error in Class File Editor unhelpful
Bug.WithStack:
I was browsing some classes that have no source available. The message under the Source not found heading in the Class File Editor is entirely unhelpful in finding a soltion to the problem.
"The JAR of this classfile belongs to the container "Required plug-in entries" To configure the source attachment, go directly to the corresponding configuration page (For example for JRE's go to Installed JRE's page in the preferences).
The example does not help. If what is a JRE? How is the JRE's configuration page going to help me. what is the JRE configuration page.
For that matter. What jar is this file in? To different things here: first the naming of the PDE class path container should be improved. The name "Required Plug-in entries" is indeed not very helpful. Created new bug 48314 for PDE.
For the help message: since the class file editor doesn't know about specific class path container it can only present a generic error message or can delegate the creation of the message to the class path container itself.
But we could improve the example wording to: "For example, if the class path container is a JRE System Library container go to Window->Preferences->Java- >Install JREs"
Asking JDT/Text for coments. Of course the delegating isn't implemented yet ;-). The message has been improved and there is now a button that directly allows to set the source.

Bug.Summery: Lock granularity of Team > Actions
Bug.WithStack:
While I was commiting a project I wanted to delete another project which was not related with the commit. However I had the windows showing that my workspace was lock. It seems to me that the granularity of the lock is too coarse. Maybe it is the lock on delete, but I just wanted to make sure that you knew about it too. Commit in the sync view uses project level locking but commit run via the context menu in other views uses workspace locking. We haven't converted all of our operations to project locks. This was somewhat intentional. This way we can test the UI responsiveness and backwards compatibility. The fact that you got a dialog was good.
Changing the title as a reminder that we may want to convert other operations too. Michael, I think this is fixed? No. Team>Commit and Team>Update still lock the entire workspace. Will address in M9. This was fixed already.

Bug.Summery: [Contributions] ordering: Actions appended to group are placed after items not in group
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20031202
This problem was uncovered by bug 47377.
We had code like so to configure the toolbar in the console view: protected void configureToolBar(IToolBarManager mgr) { mgr.add(new Separator(IConsoleConstants.LAUNCH_GROUP)); mgr.add(new Separator(IConsoleConstants.OUTPUT_GROUP)); mgr.add(fPinAction); mgr.add(fDisplayConsoleAction); }
The trouble is that if you add anything to OUTPUT_GROUP, it will actually appear after the fPinAction and fDisplayConsoleAction. This behavior comes from ContributionManager#addToGroup(groupName, item, append).
This method appends items to the end of a group by looking through the toolbar for the group separator. Then it continues iterating until it hits the next group separator or the end of the toolbar. In our case, though, we've got two items after the group separator that aren't in the group (the two actions that are there by default). The code is just looking for the start of the next group, so it ends up including these two actions as part of the OUTPUT_GROUP.
From the looks of the ContributionManager code, fixing this would require the manager to store more state than it currently does. As it iterates over the items after the start of a group, it has no way of knowing when it gets to items that aren't in the group (there's no state stored to remember which group an item is in). doug, i think kosta has been doing some work in toolbars recently. (i couldn't find a bugzilla use name for him to cc: him though) I'm adding Kosta to the cc list, however this is a general JFace contribution manager issue, not specific to coolbar managers or menu managers.
The grouping mechanism is currently very simplistic. Recommend adding another group marker before fPinAction. The way this is handled in workbench code is to add a second separator (SEPARATOR_NAME + "-end"). This works.
I believe this bug is a "would be nice" to fix problem. Correct me if I'm wrong. Lowering to priority 4 .... Moving Dougs bugs Assigning to component owner PW
Updated as per http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Bug_Triage PW

assumes that the shell still exists, and tries to close it. However, it is
possible for the shell to be removed by other events. I've added a test for
null before calling close.
Created attachment 7210
Core dump

Bug.WithStack:
1202
It's a strange use case, but could indicate a problem that's reachable by a more conventional path:
- on the Keys preference page: -> set Active Configuration to Standard (3.0) - NEW! -> select "Help Me With..." on the Advanced Tab, OK - open a java editor - put the caret at the end of the last line (this is probably not relevant) - hold Ctrl+E for > 5 seconds; during this time the help will open up and then quickly go away repeatedly - let go of CTRL+E; if when you do so there isn't a help window popped up then no problem happens. But if there is a help window open at the time then you'll get the next attached exception. Created attachment 7078 trace doug, this stack trace is in WorkbenchKeyboard.. It is an outside case. It happens in the shell deactivation listener. It is assumes that the shell still exists, and tries to close it. However, it is possible for the shell to be removed by other events. I've added a test for null before calling close. Created attachment 7210 Core dump
This is a core dump caused by a segmentation fault in "org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.GTK_WIDGET_VISIBLE". I get this reliably while holding "Ctrl+E" with the new key configuration. The reason from the problem is new, but the triggering steps are the same. Since I can't verify this bug until the new problem is fixed, I'm re-opening this bug.... ... and re-assigning to SWT....
I'm not sure that this is a stop ship for M6, but I'm not sure of the scope of the problem. Someone should probably look at this before ok'ing the M6 build. *** Bug 49498 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 49646 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 50339 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 48084 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I'm cleaning up some old bugs.
As far as I can tell, these crashes in GTK_WIDGET_VISIBLE() are occuring because key assist dialogs were being leaked. Version 1.22 fixed one leak and worked around this problem, but a dialog was still being leaked in openMultiKeyAssistShell().
As this is no longer a problem in the current version of the code, I am closing this as WORKSFORME.

1202
It's a strange use case, but could indicate a problem that's reachable by a more conventional path:
- on the Keys preference page: -> set Active Configuration to Standard (3.0) - NEW! -> select "Help Me With..." on the Advanced Tab, OK - open a java editor - put the caret at the end of the last line (this is probably not relevant) - hold Ctrl+E for > 5 seconds; during this time the help will open up and then quickly go away repeatedly - let go of CTRL+E; if when you do so there isn't a help window popped up then no problem happens. But if there is a help window open at the time then you'll get the next attached exception. Created attachment 7078 trace doug, this stack trace is in WorkbenchKeyboard.. It is an outside case. This is a core dump caused by a segmentation fault in "org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.GTK_WIDGET_VISIBLE". I get this reliably while holding "Ctrl+E" with the new key configuration. The reason from the problem is new, but the triggering steps are the same. Since I can't verify this bug until the new problem is fixed, I'm re-opening this bug.... ... and re-assigning to SWT....
I'm not sure that this is a stop ship for M6, but I'm not sure of the scope of the problem. Someone should probably look at this before ok'ing the M6 build. *** Bug 49498 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 49646 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 50339 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 48084 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I'm cleaning up some old bugs.
As far as I can tell, these crashes in GTK_WIDGET_VISIBLE() are occuring because key assist dialogs were being leaked. Version 1.22 fixed one leak and worked around this problem, but a dialog was still being leaked in openMultiKeyAssistShell().
As this is no longer a problem in the current version of the code, I am closing this as WORKSFORME.

Bug.Summery: [Preferences] select file to display / ignore
Bug.WithStack:
In the Package Explorer and related perspectives it should be possible to specify preferences for file types that should be visible or hidden. Examples are: (for Java) *.class, (for Python) *.pyc, *.py~ and others, like *.sh or *.exe. These files should be specified in the preferences and there should be an option in the Package explorer to see all files or only those (not) listed in the preferences.
thanks for considering this feature Package Explorer's view menu > Filters...
Bug.WithOutStack:
In the Package Explorer and related perspectives it should be possible to specify preferences for file types that should be visible or hidden. Examples are: (for Java) *.class, (for Python) *.pyc, *.py~ and others, like *.sh or *.exe. These files should be specified in the preferences and there should be an option in the Package explorer to see all files or only those (not) listed in the preferences.
thanks for considering this feature Package Explorer's view menu > Filters...

Bug.Summery: [DOM] - Valid hyperlinks for Navigation
Bug.WithStack:
We need a better way of figuring out what elements are valid hyperlinks. One way of doing this is to try to do a code complete on the proposed element. If any hits come back, it is valid.
BG This is done as well as possible for now using the parser keywords utility. But once we get some form of DOM, we'll be able to figure out what's commented out or not so I'll leave this as an enhancemement request. On linux, I try to hyperlink to std when I have #include <iostream>. clocale opens up instead of iostream as expected. Would this be fixed with DOM as well? I moved my comment to a more appropriate defect, 64181. Fixed, see bug 185409.

BG This is done as well as possible for now using the parser keywords utility. But once we get some form of DOM, we'll be able to figure out what's commented out or not so I'll leave this as an enhancemement request. On linux, I try to hyperlink to std when I have #include <iostream>. clocale opens up instead of iostream as expected. Would this be fixed with DOM as well? I moved my comment to a more appropriate defect, 64181. Fixed, see bug 185409.

Bug.Summery: Improve Open Declarations
Bug.WithStack:
We need to put in a better way of navigating. Right now we do an all inclusive search based on the element selected. Once the parser can return semantic information, we should be able to improve the navigation.
- BG The first pass of Open-Declaration going to the specific declaration of a C/C++ construct is committed into HEAD. Anything that comes up now should be considered a defect, with its own bugzilla entry.

- BG The first pass of Open-Declaration going to the specific declaration of a C/C++ construct is committed into HEAD. Anything that comes up now should be considered a defect, with its own bugzilla entry.

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] Ctrl + C for copy doesn't work anymore in the console
Bug.WithStack:
Using 200312030800, the key binding Ctrl + C doesn't work anymore in the console using the default key bindings. I have to use the popup menu with the mouse. This seems to be a general problem with this build.
Previous to this build (tested in M4) I could Ctrl-C with a resource selected in the package explorer and the Ctrl-V to generate a copy of this resource.
CTRL-C does not work in any view anymore. I tried:
Debug view variables view package explorer console
The edit menu and context menu action works, but the shortcut does not. Paste and Cut seem to work though. Moving to workbench for comment -does not appear to be a debug issue. CTRL-C only seems to work in editors. I believe this is a duplicate of Bug 48024. Re-open if I'm wrong.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 48024 ***

Bug.Summery: Variables context menu actions need elipses [...]
Bug.WithStack:

Bug.Summery: Accessing bundles through old API

Lines.Line: - PluginRegistry.getDescriptor()
- PluginDescriptor.getPlugin()
- Platform.getPlugin()
- MyPlugin.getDefault()
A fix has been checked in HEAD.
- if the start of the bundle fails, a bogus plugin object is still registered
in the registry.
- in the default plugin case, the preferences and log values returned needs to
be aligned with the 3.0 story.
can this be closed?
I verified the enumerated use cases and they all gave the expected result.
Closing.

Bug.WithStack:
When a bundle is accessed through the registry API and has already been activated, the plugin descriptor returned does not contain the reference to the "plugin object".
The main area where this is exposed is for example in the preference API where the exporter run through all the active plugins and ask them to save their preferences.
The solution needs to be consistent whatever the entry points being used by the user.
The various entry points are: - PluginRegistry.getDescriptor() - PluginDescriptor.getPlugin() - Platform.getPlugin() - MyPlugin.getDefault() A fix has been checked in HEAD.
It consists in automatically registering the bundles that uses Plugin as a superclass of their activator and returning an instance of the default plugin for all the other bundles.
The issues left over are: - if the start of the bundle fails, a bogus plugin object is still registered in the registry. - in the default plugin case, the preferences and log values returned needs to be aligned with the 3.0 story. can this be closed? I verified the enumerated use cases and they all gave the expected result. Closing.

When a bundle is accessed through the registry API and has already been activated, the plugin descriptor returned does not contain the reference to the "plugin object".
The main area where this is exposed is for example in the preference API where the exporter run through all the active plugins and ask them to save their preferences.
The solution needs to be consistent whatever the entry points being used by the user.
The various entry points are: - PluginRegistry.getDescriptor() - PluginDescriptor.getPlugin() - Platform.getPlugin() - MyPlugin.getDefault() A fix has been checked in HEAD.
It consists in automatically registering the bundles that uses Plugin as a superclass of their activator and returning an instance of the default plugin for all the other bundles.
The issues left over are: - if the start of the bundle fails, a bogus plugin object is still registered in the registry. - in the default plugin case, the preferences and log values returned needs to be aligned with the 3.0 story. can this be closed? I verified the enumerated use cases and they all gave the expected result. Closing.

Bug.Summery: Code completion mistake
Selecting in GTK don't shows the element selected while clicking
Bug.WithStack:
I'm using GTK. if you select any element in any view and click with the right mouse button, the selected element appears as it's not selecting, returning to normal after the action. This is being done by the platform, which visually hides the selection in widgets like Tree whenever focus is moved elsewhere (in this case the popup menu). This also happens in Eclipse if you click on another view. This general behaviour can be seen in other native apps like gtk-demo, and I dislike it very much, but cannot change it.
There's probably a request in gnome's bugzilla to change this behaviour. If you find one then let me know and I'll vote for it <g>.
But it's new for me, I don't remember this behaviour in previous versions of GTK... When you say "previous versions of gtk", do you mean previous builds of Eclipse- for-gtk, or have you recently upgraded the gtk libraries on your computer?
If you mean that you have seen this since upgrading your gtk libraries then yes, we have seen this change at the gtk level. If I use gtk 2.0.6 then the selections are not hidden, but if I use gtk 2.2.1 then the selections are hidden.
Assigning to GG. Closing since it's a gtk thing.

Bug.Summery: Changed Java files no longer editable, raises IllegalArgumentException

Lines.Line: 1. create an empty Java class in some package
2. in the Java editor, change "class" to "interface" by hand and
rename the name of the class by hand (e.g. add an "I" in front of the name)
3. JDT immediately shows a red mark and a code-assist suggesting to
recompile the compilation unit w/ the new name, or to revert to the old
name. Choose to recompile/refactor w/ the new name.
4. the Package Explorer and editor updates w/ the new name, and the
"Java AST creation" error appears. The editor loses focus, any attempt
to click/type in the editor raises the error again and defocuses the
editor. It is impossible to type anything in the editor for that file.
5. close Eclipse and open Eclipse again. Open the changed file in the
Java editor, and the same error still gets triggered.

Bug.WithStack:
I'm running Eclipse 3.0 milestone 5 with Sun JDK 1.4.2
I changed a Java class into an interface by hand and renamed it by hand, which triggers the error log message: "An internal error occurred during Java AST Creation" and the progress message: "ERROR: Java AST Creation: An internal error occurred during Java AST Creation".
Once this error is triggered, any attempt to click on the Java editor with the changed file triggers another error and defocuses the editor, making the file effectively uneditable. A workaround solution is to copy text (copy/select still works), delete the file, and then recreate the file from scratch.
I tried to pinpoint the steps to reproduce this problem, and it appears to be the following steps:
1. create an empty Java class in some package
2. in the Java editor, change "class" to "interface" by hand and rename the name of the class by hand (e.g. add an "I" in front of the name)
3. JDT immediately shows a red mark and a code-assist suggesting to recompile the compilation unit w/ the new name, or to revert to the old name. Choose to recompile/refactor w/ the new name.
4. the Package Explorer and editor updates w/ the new name, and the "Java AST creation" error appears. The editor loses focus, any attempt to click/type in the editor raises the error again and defocuses the editor. It is impossible to type anything in the editor for that file.
5. close Eclipse and open Eclipse again. Open the changed file in the Java editor, and the same error still gets triggered.
This error may be related to bug #47617 ("Java AST Creation")
The stack trace from the error is as follows:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTNode.setSourceRange(ASTNode.java:1486) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:701) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.buildBodyDeclarations (ASTConverter.java:244) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:183) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTConverter.convert(ASTConverter.java:81) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.AST.parseCompilationUnit(AST.java:354) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.AST.parseCompilationUnit(AST.java:247) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.viewsupport.SelectionListenerWithASTManager$PartLis tenerGroup.computeAST(SelectionListenerWithASTManager.java:106) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.viewsupport.SelectionListenerWithASTManager$PartLis tenerGroup.calculateASTandInform(SelectionListenerWithASTManager.java:116) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.viewsupport.SelectionListenerWithASTManager$1.run (SelectionListenerWithASTManager.java:92) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:62) Close as duplicate of bug 47396.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 47396 *** Verified that this does not happen with build I200312160010.
But, even strictly following described scenario, I didn't succeed to reproduce either with 3.0 M5 or 2.1.2 build!?
One question about scenario is: are you sure that code-assist provide recompile/refactor actions? I've used Quick-fix "Rename compilation unit to 'IX.java'" and refactoring in package explorer and both actions works without any AST error message.
Apologies - you're correct, I was using Quick-fix ("Rename compilation unit to 'IX.java'"), not code-assist.
Also, for some reason I'm no longer able to reproduce the error either. Beyond installing Java Spider on my copy of 3.0 M5, there hasn't been any changes to my Eclipse setup.
It's probably best then to close this bug and not worry about it, since it appeared to be pretty spurious, and M6 will probably not encounter this problem anyhow. Thanks for looking into this.

Bug.Summery: Need to be able to provide an imported package.
Bug.WithStack:
Currently the framework does not allow for a bundle to provide a package that is imported. This means that a bundle will not be able to provide a package that it also exports if the framework chooses a different package version to make available to the framework from another bundle.
The search order for provided packages should be enhanced to include looking in a bundles imports for a package that it provides. Fix released in HEAD. Thomas review and close. The fix needed to also include the additional lookup for resource loading. I added this code and checked in the fix.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Currently the framework does not allow for a bundle to provide a package that is imported. This means that a bundle will not be able to provide a package that it also exports if the framework chooses a different package version to make available to the framework from another bundle.
The search order for provided packages should be enhanced to include looking in a bundles imports for a package that it provides. Fix released in HEAD. Thomas review and close. The fix needed to also include the additional lookup for resource loading. I added this code and checked in the fix.

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] Add Folders Selection Dialog should not list closed projects.

Lines.Line: - Hides closed projects by default
- Adds a checkbox to control whether to hide or to show closed projects
- Add the ability to open a closed project by double-clicking on it

Bug.WithStack:
If you edit a debug configuration for a remote java application, and go to the source tab, and un-select use default source lookup path, and then choose advanced , add folders, you will be presented with a list of projects in your workspace including _closed_ project which in this dialog you can't open. You should only be shown projects were are open and have folders you could possibly select. Not for 3.0 Reopening now that 3.0 has shipped Created attachment 46679 patch_folder_source_dialog.diff
Here is a patch to improve the Source Folder Dialog with these things: - Hides closed projects by default - Adds a checkbox to control whether to hide or to show closed projects - Add the ability to open a closed project by double-clicking on it
I hope this covers all your needs :-) Created attachment 46680 patch_folder_source_dialog_updated.diff
Sorry, forgot the updates of the SourceLookupUIMessages. Created attachment 46681 patch_folder_source_dialog_update2.diff
Sorry, I'm a bit tired. Here is another update. The changes: - replaced TreeSelection with IStructuredSelection to generalize the selection Thanks for the patch. Assigning a 3.3 milestone so that this patch gets reviewed for 3.3 sigh...reassigning for 3.4. I'm only marking a few bugs 3.4 at this time and will get fixes in before triaging the other unmarked bugs. That way it won't be delayed again. This is actually a debug dialog change, so moving to debug. Sorry it sat in platform UI for so long. ;-(
The patch extends the functionality of the dialog to include a toggle that lets you decide if closed projects should be presented.
A simpler approach would be to disable the apply button when a closed project is selected. This was approach platform UI took in bug #82541 for the SaveAsDialog. fixed in HEAD
I did not apply the patch because we do not want to allow the workspace to be altered via the launch dialog (or child dialogs thereof). Since the projects cannot be opened, there is no need for an option to show closed projects because you can't do anything with them either way.
I did however add a simple viewer filter to not show closed projects. please verify Curtis W Verified

Bug.Summery: java errors in Task window not visible
Bug.WithStack:
as reported in Bug 45956#c5 , I have 16 bugs from an uninstalled plugin, I don't know how to get rid off.
Worse even, dozens of new Java errors are no longer added to the task list as they did before - going to add a screenshot next! Created attachment 7080 screenshot
using Version: 2.1.2 Build id: 200311030802 Is autobuild turned on? Do you have any filtering turned on in the tasks list? Is it reproducible? finally I solved the problem. easystruts copied the jars in a directory on its own. When removing plugin manually (a systematic way to remove a plugin would be great Bug 47959), I removed that directory as well. What I didn't realize that the plugin also had added all these jars a second time to the project's java build path. Due to that, the project wouldn't rebuild anymore and thus the Java errors were no longer shown. So, once I realized that every jar was in the build path with two different paths and removed the outdated entries, it compiled again and the java errors were visible again.
====> This experience is one more reason to have a plugin uninstall that automatically removes all its traces - including jars added to the build path that are no longer needed. Closing as invalid.
